mxCell.value:
• While doing Question Answering it becomes important for LLM models to use Chain of Thoughts(CoT) reasoning.
  • Without CoT models hallucinate and rush to an answer which might be wrong.
  • At present, prompting is used to make LLMs use CoT for reasoning and arriving at answers.
  • This research explores the possibility of doing CoT without prompting by avoiding greedy sampling and using top-k sampling
  • Explore alternate encoding path using top-k sampling at different step. Presents COT Decoding
  • Out of all different path choose one which provides average maximum post-softmax probability of top two tokens for answer tokens(Averaged for multiple tokens for answer).
  • Answer token is compute either for maths case as last numerical value or simple by adding extra text to predict answer then find that answer in the predicted paths.
Review of paper "Chain-of-Thought Reasoning without Prompting"

• QA without Chain of Thoughts, The predicted answer is wrong as Nicolas Cage was born in 1964 which is an Even year not Odd as predicted
  • When using top-7 value for decoding first token then following with greedy decoding leads to correct answer with CoT

User Question 
without Prompting

Eg: Was Nicolas Cage born in an even or odd year?
Large Language Model
Fig.1. Question Answering using default greedy sampling vs top-7 at step-0 without Chain-of-thought

Answer:
Odd
(Actual Answer: Even(1964))
Greedy Sampling based on Top-1 value

Answer:
Cage was born in 1964, an even year.
Top-7 sampling at step 0 then greedy decoding

CoT Decoding

  • Suggests using top-k sampling which could lead to different output. 
  • In the below example we also get CoT at Top-7, Top4 cases thus arriving at correct answer
1964, an even year
Fig.3. COT Decoding

Top-1: Nicholas
Top-2: Odd
Top-3: Even
Top-4: 1
Top-5: He
.
.
.
Top-7: Cage
Nicholas Cage was born in Odd year
Odd
1964, an even year
Cage was born in 1964, an even year.
Decoding at step-0
Continue greedy decoding after first token decoding

User Question 
without Prompting

Eg: Was Nicolas Cage born in an even or odd year?

Example from the paper:
```
[GSM8K] Kylar went to the store to buy glasses for his new apartment. One glass costs $5, but every second
glass costs only 60% of the price. Kylar wants to buy 16 glasses. How much does he need to pay for them?
Greedy path:
𝑘 = 0: $60.00 (0.029)
Alternative top-𝑘 paths:
𝑘 = 1: 60 (0.058)
𝑘 = 2: Kylar needs to pay $60 for 16 glasses. (0.058)
. . .
𝑘 = 7: If Kylar buys 16 glasses, he will pay $60. (0.032)
𝑘 = 9: We can calculate the price of 16 glasses by multiplying the price of one glass by 16. However, we
need to remember that every second glass costs only 60% of the price. Therefore, we need to multiply the
price of one glass by 16 and then subtract 40% of the price of 8 glasses. 16 x 5 = 80 8 x 5 = 40 40 x 0.4 =
16 80 – 16 = 64 Kylar needs to pay $64 for 16 glasses. (0.994)
```
  • Finds out the maximum post-softmax probabilities for answer comparing the top two tokens predicted for answer.





  • There can be multiple tokens for answer so xt represents all the answer tokens and the above delta value is averaged for all such tokens.
  • This measures how sure the model is about the answer prediction.
  • In the above example model while giving wrong prediction is not sure about the prediction and same is reflected in the values(in blue color) while the correct answer case the answer delta score is much higher.
User Question
Large Language Model
top-k sampling at step 0 followed by greedy decdoing
Answer certainty or Delta calculation for answer tokens
Fig.2. General Pipeline proposed. Created for step-0 top-k sampling but branching can occur at any later step as well
Pick the Answer using Weighted Aggregation
CoT Decoding

Identifying Answer:
  • We need answer tokens to calculate above delta. 
    • Maths reasoning task: Get the last numerical value
    • Set-based reasoning task: Final option provided
    • Rest of tasks: Extend model output with "So the answer is". The answer which we got then can be treated as answer string. Discarding the extended output.
Branching at other steps:
  • Branching at initial steps can help diversity while conversely intermediate stage branching can also yield correct CoT paths
Aggregation:
  • Instead of taking majority voting, weighted aggregation is done for the top-k paths. This increases the stability.

Experiments Related


Datasets:
  • GSM8K
  • MultiAirth
  • Year Parity
Models:
  • Palm
  • Mistral-7B
  • Gemma-7B
